entry.title: Dublin SAP Community
entry.content:
I want to welcome you to the new Dublin Community Group at SAP Community. This group is for everyone involved in SAP  who wants to learn more about both the emerging new technologies and existing SAP suite. I have been involved with SAP for close to 30 years, having intially started out as an ABAPper implementing a 3.1h SAP system and eventually working my way up to Head of Development of a small software development company specialising in BTP based applications.

I believe there is a great appetite among SAP professionals who want to understand where SAP is going and how we can be a part of that journey. My goal with this group is to build a shared resource where we can connect to one another and create a space which will enable its membership to actively engage with SAP technologies while at the same time creating a support structure for us to find our way through the new world of AI.

As the local event organiser I'll be looking at creating and facilitating meetups and discussions to get us there and hope you can join us at these meetups.

Please feel welcome to connect to me at www.linkedin.com/in/alanmarshall and I hope to meet you over the coming months.

entry.title: Hello SAP Community Chemnitz
entry.content:
*** english below ***

Willkommen in der SAP Community Local Group Chemnitz!

Diese Gruppe ist eine lokale Plattform f√ºr alle, die sich in Chemnitz und der Region f√ºr SAP interessieren. Ganz gleich, ob du t√§glich mit SAP-L√∂sungen arbeitest, als Berater:in, Entwickler:in oder Analyst:in t√§tig bist, studierst oder einfach neugierig auf SAP-Themen bist ‚Äì du bist hier herzlich willkommen.

Unser Ziel ist es, einen Raum f√ºr pers√∂nlichen Austausch und Vernetzung zu schaffen. Wir sind √ºberzeugt davon, dass der direkte Austausch von Angesicht zu Angesicht besonders wertvoll ist, um Erfahrungen zu teilen, Ideen zu diskutieren und voneinander zu lernen.

Chemnitz und die umliegende Region bieten eine starke Basis aus Industrie, Technologie und Innovation, erg√§nzt durch eine vielf√§ltige akademische Landschaft mit Hochschulen und Forschungseinrichtungen als wichtigen Teil des lokalen √ñkosystems. Wir m√∂chten Menschen aus Industrie, Beratung, Wissenschaft und dar√ºber hinaus miteinander vernetzen.

Unser erster Fokus liegt klar auf pers√∂nlichen Treffen vor Ort. Geplant sind entspannte Meetups und informelle Zusammenk√ºnfte wie ein Stammtisch, bei denen sich SAP-Interessierte und SAP-Professionals austauschen, voneinander lernen und gemeinsam ein starkes lokales Netzwerk aufbauen k√∂nnen. Informationen zu kommenden Veranstaltungen teilen wir hier in der Gruppe.

Diese Community lebt von der Beteiligung ihrer Mitglieder. Alle, die die Idee des offenen Austauschs und der Zusammenarbeit teilen, sind eingeladen, sich einzubringen, Themen vorzuschlagen oder zuk√ºnftige Events mitzugestalten. Wenn du dich aktiver an der Organisation oder Kuration der Gruppe beteiligen m√∂chtest, melde dich gern.

Wir freuen uns darauf, eine lebendige SAP Community in Chemnitz aufzubauen und viele spannende Gespr√§che pers√∂nlich vor Ort zu f√ºhren.

Willkommen in der Gruppe!

Viele Gr√º√üe
Pierre und Jens

Welcome to the SAP Community Local Group Chemnitz!

This group is a local platform for everyone in and around Chemnitz who is interested in SAP. Whether you work with SAP solutions in your daily business, are a consultant, developer, analyst, student, or simply curious about SAP topics, you are very welcome to join us.

Our main goal is to create a space for personal exchange and networking. We strongly believe in the value of meeting face to face, sharing experiences directly, and discussing challenges and ideas in an open and relaxed atmosphere.

Chemnitz and the surrounding region offer a strong foundation of industry, technology, and innovation, supported by a diverse academic landscape with universities and research institutions as an important part of the local ecosystem. We want to connect people from industry, consulting, academia, and beyond who are part of this ecosystem.

Our first focus is clearly on meeting in person. We are planning relaxed meetups and informal get-togethers (Stammtisch) where SAP professionals and interested people can exchange ideas, learn from each other, and grow a strong local network. You will find updates on upcoming events right here in the group.

This community lives from participation. Everyone who shares the idea of open exchange and collaboration is invited to contribute, bring in topics, or help shape future events. If you are interested in getting more actively involved in organizing or curating the group, feel free to reach out.

We are looking forward to building a vibrant SAP community in Chemnitz and to many great conversations in person and on site.

Welcome to the group!

Best regards
Pierre and Jens

entry.title: SAP Community Voice: AI Insights, SAP Community Memories, and What‚Äôs Coming in 2026!
entry.content:
Today marks the final edition of Community Voice for 2025, and we are happy to bring you great featured blog posts, valuable insights from one of our SAP Mentors, and wonderful memories from SAP TechEd. Looking back, we are incredibly proud of our SAP community members for their contributions, energy, and commitment to helping others, sharing experiences, and making the SAP ecosystem an inspiring place to be part of. 

This edition is also a moment to express our gratitude to you, our readers, who continuously engage with our content. Without your support and participation, none of this would be possible. Thank you for being here and for showing up to so many other community members. 

While this newsletter takes a short break during the holiday season, we want to let you know that we will be back at the beginning of January 2026. For now, let‚Äôs look at what has been happening in the SAP Community over the past few weeks and what exciting events are planned for the year ahead! 

Let‚Äôs dive in! 

Featured Blog Posts

Reflections about how far AI will go  

The more we talk about AI, the more people tend to pick sides. Whether you like it or not, the implementation of Artificial Intelligence is accelerating everywhere, and this year SAP demonstrated how well it is prepared to bring powerful AI solutions to its customers. SAP Community member and former SAP employee Pierre Col, who recently retired, opened an important discussion about this topic. In his blog post, he highlights how strongly SAP is positioned in the market and showcases the power of its AI offerings. At the same time, he raises concerns about the impact that AI, and humanoid robots in particular, may have on human employment. Overall, this is a valuable blog post that encourages thoughtful reflection on what the near future may look like and invites the community to share ideas, perspectives, and engage in meaningful discussion in the comments. 

Read Pierre full blog post here 

Guide to Accessibility in SAP Fiori/UI5 for beginners  

If you are looking to understand what accessibility really is in UI development, common pitfalls in UI5 apps and how to start building accessible features without feeling overwhelmed, this blog post is for you. SAP¬¥s Guruprasad, shares a personal journey of discovering why accessibility is not extra work, but a fundamental part of building usable applications, particularly when working with SAP Fiori and UI5. Through practical examples, he introduces useful tools and techniques for testing accessibility, including keyboard-only navigation, screen readers, contrast checkers, and browser inspection tools. This is a beginner-friendly and practical guide for everyone who wants to build inclusive, high-quality SAP UI applications.  

Read Guruprasad full blog post here 

SAP Mentor Leonardo Araujo insights on AI journey at SAP TechEd 2025  

One of the most valuable aspects of SAP TechEd 2025 was the insightful sessions delivered by experienced developers and industry experts. We had the pleasure of hearing from many SAP Mentors and Champions who brought important conversations to the spotlight, and one of the standout sessions was presented by SAP Mentor Leonardo Araujo. His session was based on his earlier blog post‚ÄùThe AI Stack Is Ready ‚Äî Are You? The Challenge No Longer Is Technology‚Äú. Leonardo explained that the AI technology stack, especially for generative and agent-based AI, is already largely in place. Capabilities such as secure AI, RAG scenarios, agent building, orchestration, and flexible LLM choices are now well supported by SAP BTP and reinforced by recent SAP innovations announced at SAP TechEd. He also emphasized key realities of generative AI, including its probabilistic nature, the critical importance of clearly defined problem statements, and the risks of applying AI to broken or poorly designed processes. Therefore, Leonardo shared practical recommendations around experimentation, fail-fast approaches, and the journey from pilot to production. His content is a must-read, offering valuable insights into why some AI pilots fail and how organizations can achieve success. 

Read Leonardo Araujo full blog post here 

SAP Cloud ALM: Codeless Automation for RISE Transitions 

Nowadays, regression testing often becomes a challenge because of the necessity teams need to balance thorough test coverage with the pressure to release quickly. SAP¬¥s Paulo Boschetti explores how Tricentis Test Automation for SAP integrated with SAP Cloud ALM can help teams address this challenge in a more practical way. Paulo explains that tools only succeed when supported by strong testing practices, clear strategies, and skilled teams. While Tricentis TTA offers a powerful, codeless, and SaaS-based approach, its real value comes from enabling functional teams to actively participate in automation rather than replacing testing expertise. Considering real-world implementations in Latin America, particularly during RISE with SAP transitions and S/4HANA upgrades, he shows how this solution significantly reduces regression testing effort and accelerates delivery cycles. He also makes sure to remind readers to‚ÄØinvest equally in your team by training them and supporting skills development.  

Read Paulo Boschetti full blog post here 

Community News 

SAP TechEd 2025: Moshe Naveh Recap  

SAP TechEd 2025 was definitely a highlight of the year for the SAP Community, and Community Advocate Moshe Naveh shared an engaging recap of his experience, highlighting some of the great moments he spent with community members in Berlin and Bengaluru. In his blog post, he reflects on how refreshing it was to return to on-site events, especially since his last SAP TechEd attendance was seven years ago. Moshe also encourages community members to keep the momentum going through online gatherings and continued engagement. For those feeling inspired to share their own stories, he previously published a helpful guide on using an AI-based simplified blogging methodology, making it easier for anyone to start contributing and sharing their experiences with the community. 

SAP Inside Track Gurugram 2025 

At the end of November, one of the most anticipated events for the SAP Community Gurugram location group took place: SAP Inside Track Gurugram 2025. The event offered a full day of learning and idea exchange among community members and SAP developers, consultants, architects and many more. Hosted at SAP Labs India in Gurugram, the event opened with a keynote by Sindhu Gangadharan, Managing Director of SAP Labs India, Head of SAP Customer Innovation Services, and SAP Chairperson of NASSCOM. Alongside the keynote, the agenda covered a wide range of SAP topics presented by multiple speakers and lots of network breaks. The day concluded with a closing ceremony followed by snacks and informal talks, giving attendees the opportunity to connect. If you would like to explore more highlights (or check if you appear in any of the photos) be sure to read SAP¬¥s Neeraj Manocha latest blog post here for a full recap of the SIT Gurugram! 

SAP ALM Summit North America 2026

To keep the energy going, we would like to remind everyone about the upcoming SAP ALM Summit North America 2026! This event is the chance to boost your ALM value by learning from real-life customer experiences. Expand your knowledge through hands-on labs and attending expert-led sessions.  Some of the amazing speakers that will be presenting at the event are Tim Steuer - VP Customer Communications & Relations SAP SE, S√∂ren Ruder- Head of Customer Experience & Solutions (CXS) SAP SE, Joshua Greenbaum- Principal of Enterprise Applications Consulting EAC and Todd Crandall- Head of Customer Services & Delivery SAP North America. Make sure to register for the event here: SAP ALM Summit NA 2026. 

2026 Upcoming Events

As 2025 comes to an end, we are already looking ahead to 2026 with many exciting plans! SAP community location groups have already added dates for upcoming gatherings to their agendas, giving you the perfect opportunity to mark your calendar early and plan ahead. These events are a great chance to connect, learn, and meet fellow SAP community members in your area.  

Check out the list below to see the events already scheduled for 2026: 

  • 20 of January: SAP CodeJam - Build AI services using the CAP and Generative AI Hub (Bielefeld, Germany) 
  • 21 of January: SAP CodeJam - Getting started with Generative AI Hub on SAP AI Core ( Hyderabad, India ) 
  • 22 of January: SAP CodeJam ABAP: SAP BTP, ABAP Environment & RAP ( Hyderabad, India ) 
  • 23 of January: SAP Stammtisch Wroclaw - January Edition! (Registration is closed) 
  • 29 of January: SAP Build: Advanced Event Mesh - Event based SAP Build Process Automation (Bengaluru, India) 
  • 09 of February: Build AI services using the CAP and Generative AI Hub (Pune, India) 
  • 26 of February: ‚ÄØBuild AI services using the CAP and Generative AI Hub (Gent, Belgium) 
  • 14 of March: SAP Inside Track Joinville 2026 ‚Äì Brasil 
  • 17 of March: SAP TALK WOMEN CWB 2026- Curitiba, Brasil 
  • 14 - 16 of April: SAP ALM Summit NA 2026- Pennsylvania, United States
  • 26 of September: SAP Inside Track Porto 2026 - Portugal 
  • 31 of October: SAP Inside Track Fortaleza 2026- Brasil  

Happy Holidays!  

We would like to express our sincere gratitude to the entire SAP community for the passion, collaboration, and knowledge you share every day. Your contributions and willingness to support one another are what makes this community so special. 2025 was a wonderful year, filled with meaningful lessons and lasting memories, whether online or on-site. Every SAP Inside Track, Stammtisch, meet-up, and even informal conversation made a significant impact, strengthening our connections and contributing to the growth of our community. We wish you a joyful holiday season with peace, happiness, and time with loved ones. We look forward to continuing this journey together in 2026. Happy holidays from all of us in the SAP Community!

entry.title: Stop Building From Scratch: Unlocking SAP Cloud Integration‚Äôs Standard Content
entry.content:
A few months ago, I joined a project where the integration team was spending weeks designing mappings, data models, and error-handling frameworks for processes that were all quite common in business environments.

Sales Orders, Customers, Accounts and other Business Objects

The system landscape was straightforward:
SAP S/4HANA on the backend, Salesforce as the CRM, and the business just wanted data to flow seamlessly between the two.

The team had already started building everything manually:

  • Canonical models for Business Partners
  • Transformations to Salesforce Accounts
  • Retry frameworks and error handling
After Six weeks of design workshops, not a single iFlow was built yet.
At one point, I asked: ‚ÄúHave we checked the Discover space in SAP CI for pre-built Salesforce content?‚Äù
The answer was a confident:  "No. We always build our own.‚Äù
 
Fast forward a few hours later, we sat together and opened Discover.

Most of what they were planning to design had already been developed by SAP, ready to use, specifically for S/4HANA to Salesforce integration, available in the Discover space of SAP Cloud Integration.

There are pre-built integration flows for:

  • Business Partner ‚Üî Account
  • Order ‚Üî Opportunity status
  • Customer master synchronization
  • Error handling and notifications

Instead of designing everything from scratch, all they needed to do was deploy, configure, and extend where necessary.

And this experience has repeated itself across multiple customers, industries, and systems, teams spending months designing integrations that SAP had already delivered as out-of-the-box content.

Not because the team enjoy reinventing the wheel,
but because they simply didn‚Äôt know the wheel already existed.

So, this blog is for everyone who is still building everything from scratch, not because they want to, but because they don‚Äôt know that SAP already provides out-of-the-box integration content.

 

What Is Standard Integration Content?

In simple terms, it‚Äôs SAP‚Äôs way of saying: ‚ÄúHere are prebuilt integration flows, mappings, APIs, and business objects. You don‚Äôt need to start from zero.‚Äù

This content is:

  • Built by SAP
  • Delivered as part of your Integration Suite license
  • Designed for common business processes
  • Packaged with best practices and enterprise patterns

Think of it as Lego blocks.
SAP gives you the pieces, and you assemble what fits your scenario.

 

But How Much Content Are We Talking About?

Here‚Äôs the scale people don‚Äôt realize:

700+ Integration Packages and nearly 4000 iFlows delivered out-of-the-box by SAP.

 

This isn‚Äôt just ‚Äúsome content‚Äù.
It‚Äôs an entire ecosystem of reusable assets built to accelerate enterprise integration.

 

Reality Check: Actual time needed to build integrations

In many organizations, a typical integration project goes like this:

Classic approach (manual build)

  • 6‚Äì8 weeks of design
  • 6‚Äì10 weeks of development
  • Testing + refinements

Total: 12‚Äì20 weeks

 

With Standard Integration Content

  • Deploy existing flows
  • Configure mappings
  • Tailor business-specific logic

Total: 2‚Äì6 weeks

What‚Äôs in the Box?

Standard content includes:
  • Pre-built iFlows
  • Value mappings
  • Event-based integrations
  • Error handling logic
  • Industry-specific templates
  • Configuration Guide
Some packages even include complete integration scenarios. You don‚Äôt just get sample content, You get deployment-ready accelerators.
 

Out-of-the-Box‚Äù Means Out-of-the-Budget

Here‚Äôs the part that surprises most people: There is no additional cost for this. As long as you have a valid license for SAP Integration Suite, you already have access to the standard integration content.

There‚Äôs no marketplace fee.
There‚Äôs no premium tier.
There‚Äôs no ‚Äúenterprise unlock‚Äù.

 

Where Do You Find It?

If you‚Äôve never explored it, here‚Äôs how to get started:
  1. Open SAP Integration Suite
  2. Go to Discover
  3. Search for apps or domains (e.g., SuccessFactors, Salesforce, Ariba)

 

  1. Review package
  2. Copy and adapt

 

As soon as you copy the package, it gets visible in the design tab of your tenant, Now the package is ready to be used. You can configure, modify and make it ready to use.

If you‚Äôre new to SAP CI, take 30 minutes and browse, it will change how you approach integration forever.

 

Why Use Standard Content?

Here‚Äôs the business value:
  1. Faster delivery
    Skip the blueprinting for obvious processes.
  2. Lower risk
    SAP delivers content that is tested, versioned, and updated.
  3. SAP Support and Maintenance
    Support is provided by SAP and updates are released if any.
  4. Best practices by default
    You don‚Äôt have to reinvent canonical models or data mappings.
  5. More time for innovation
    Deliver outcomes, not just interfaces.

My favorite way to summarize it: SAP builds 70-80% of the technical plumbing. You only customize what makes your business unique.

 

Customize, Don‚Äôt Copy-Paste

A common misconception is: ‚ÄúStandard content means I have to use it the way it comes.‚Äù
The answer is: "No"

You can:

  • Extend mappings
  • Add enrichment logic
  • Build wrapper services
  • Add error or retry mechanisms

 SAP expects you to tailor it.

The goal is not reuse OR customize.
The goal is reuse AND customize smartly.

But here‚Äôs a very important nuance that many teams overlook:

When you directly modify a standard integration flow, SAP continues to support the standard baseline, but not the customized version. From that point on, you own the lifecycle of the changes.  And honestly, it makes complete sense. Because once you‚Äôve edited it, SAP has no visibility into:

  • What you changed
  • Why you changed it
  • Whether your changes break functional assumptions

 So they can‚Äôt be accountable for something they didn‚Äôt design or test.

This doesn‚Äôt mean ‚Äúdon‚Äôt customize‚Äù.

There are smarter patterns teams follow to balance reuse + support:

  • Overlay mappings instead of rewriting
  • Wrap standard content in a parent orchestrator
  • Avoid editing the original package unless absolutely necessary
  • Clone only when you fully ‚Äúown‚Äù the lifecycle

 In other words:

Standard content should be reused wherever feasible and extended cautiously when required. Customization should be undertaken only when full ownership and support responsibility can be assumed, ensuring faster delivery and long-term stability.
 

But Let‚Äôs Be Honest

Standard content is not perfect.

Sometimes:

  • The business process doesn‚Äôt match your reality
  • Documentation is light
  • Customization becomes unavoidable

That‚Äôs okay. Think of standard content as a foundation, not a finished building.

It saves you weeks of work.Not all the work.

 

The Mindset Shift

The biggest barrier to adoption is not technology, its culture. Many Integration Teams have this default behavior:
‚ÄúOpen Integration Suite ‚Üí Create iFlow ‚Üí Start designing‚Äù
But the better question is: ‚ÄúHas SAP already solved this problem for me?‚Äù
 
We don‚Äôt get awards for reinventing wheels, We get value from delivering outcomes faster.
 

Real-World Examples

Here are real scenarios where standard content gave teams a head start:
  • Salesforce Integration with SAP Signavio Process Intelligence
  • SAP S/4HANA Integration with Coupa
  • SAP S/4HANA Integration with Zycus

What would normally take 6-8 weeks of design + development
sometimes went live in 2-3 weeks with tailoring.

 

Wrapping Up

SAP Cloud Integration doesn‚Äôt just give you a platform. It gives you content, knowledge, and patterns out-of-the-box.
And yet, so many organizations overlook it spending time, budget, and energy on things that are already there.
 
So the next time someone says: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll build the integration from scratch.‚Äù
Ask them: ‚ÄúOr should we check what SAP already provides?‚Äù
It‚Äôs a small question with massive impact.
 

Join the Conversation

Standard Integration Content in SAP CI continues to grow because practitioners share real-world experiences, gaps, and ideas. If you come across a business scenario or integration use case where standard content is missing or doesn‚Äôt fully meet your needs, don‚Äôt keep it to yourself, share it in the comments or reach out. Your feedback truly matters.

Have you already used Standard Integration Content in SAP Cloud Integration? What worked well, what didn‚Äôt, and what surprised you along the way? Share your experiences, lessons, and tips, because the SAP community learns fastest when we learn together and every insight helps make the standard content more relevant for everyone.

Hope this helps!

 

Cheers,
Punith

entry.title: Enhancements to SAP Community - December 2025
entry.content:
Kudos are now Likes 

The year is ending, and it is also time to say goodbye to our Kudos! Starting now, our thumbs-up for blog posts, comments, and all types of content is again Likes. This change comes from the feedback we have received from our users and our desire to make the platform more intuitive to use. From now on, whenever you read a valuable post or want to show your support, you can simply press the Like button and show your appreciation to the author and wider community. 

End of the pilot for blog post reading view 

Back in August this year, we announced the start of the pilot reading experience for blog posts. This pilot began in response to users who felt that readability was affected and that too much information on the page could be distracting. The right sidebar column for widgets was removed to enable a full-width blog post reading view. However, after analyzing users feedback provided to us in the comments section of the announcement post, we decided to return to the old format, and have therefore now reintroduced the sidebar column for the blog post article reading view.  
On large displays, with the text flowing to a 100% horizontally, it was clear that the reading experience did not improve. If there is any interest, we could try a 4/5 width reading view, like the new view for the individual SAP Managed tag pages. The 4/5 width view is a view without the sidebar column and would ensure the text doesn‚Äôt flow to 100% width on large displays. Please let us know in the comments section below.  

October ‚Äì November platform updates 

With the start of the SAP TechEd month, we all got caught up in the excitement of the on-site events. But while all of this was happening, great new features were also released on our SAP Community Platform. The main enhancements were:  

  • Filter My Content by Interaction Style: It is now possible to filter the My Content Page by interaction style to make it easier to find posts you've created. There are separate tabs for the various post tabs including Answers and Replies to posts. 

Before: 

After: 

 

  • TKB Documents: The last edited date has been added to TKB Documents to indicate the date on which a TKB was last updated in addition to it's creation date. This will make it easier for you to identify in the activity feeds if an article has been updated since it was first published. 

Before: 

After:  

 

  • New Progression Badges for Discussion: We launched another badge progression set, which is designed specifically to recognize members who start discussions. You will be rewarded with the first badge for starting your first discussion, the second for three discussions, the third for ten, and the fourth for twenty. The biggest milestone is the fifth badge, awarded for starting fifty discussions in the community. Caroleigh Deneen gave more details in her blog post here. 

 

  • Preserving the integrity of the community's content: It is highly recommended that if you need to use GenAI tools to draft, plan, and refine your content, the final text still reflects your personal expertise. Now the ‚ÄúGenAI Assisted Content‚Äù label can also be found and added. SAP¬¥s‚ÄØAnne Petteroe‚ÄØexplained all the details on‚ÄØher blog post here, and the examples of unacceptable usage. The complete‚ÄØgenerative AI guidelines for the SAP Community‚ÄØcan be found in our‚ÄØWelcome Corner‚ÄØgroup.‚ÄØ 

2025 Enhancements Recap!  

This year was full of new features and enhancements for the SAP Community. It is always good to look back and reflect on everything that was delivered at the end of the year. So, in case you missed any announcements or would like to know more about them, here is the complete list of everything that was delivered in 2025: 

January Enhancements - Read the full blog post here‚ÄØ  

  • "Creation Date" sort option added to viewing discussion threads within Groups 
  • ‚ÄúSubscribe‚Äù button to turn on all the notifications when comments and answers are posted to a blog post or a discussion. 
  • Time for Event Save the Date pages automatically adjusted accordingly to the user's browser time zone setting.

February Enhancements‚ÄØ- Read the full blog post here   

  • SAP Managed tag picker for search results sorted alphabetically‚ÄØand shows all results matching the search term 
  • Improvement to the SAP Managed tag page to show only the latest posts, side widgets removed, preview of the posts and Kudo counter was added  
  • Inclusion of BlueSky icon and link in notifications. Find our SAP Community profile at BlueSky here. 

March Enhancements - Read the full blog post here 

  • Update on the SAP Community Privacy Statement, with SAP Consulting Capability process description and addition of locations for the country and regional provision section 
  • Editor Bar fully expanded for better usage 
  • SAP Champions and Mentors identification by their logos 
  • Event reminders for 24h prior the event start 
  • Board selector list organized and sequenced inside ‚ÄúCreate a Post‚Äù 
  • Fixed Bugs 

We launched blog posts to the Community Corner group - Read the full blog post here   

  • For a better organization and optimize the accessibility for community content (that is not directly related to Technology or SAP products topics), a new blog post board has been created in the Community Corner group. This board is open to everyone for publishing a wide range of topics related to the SAP Community, including non-work-related content. On our side, we will use the new board to highlight active contributors, share updates about SAP Champions and Mentors, and post news related to SAP and community events. Existing Blog It Forward and Monthly Member Spotlight posts have already been moved there. The group is now also easily accessible via the main Groups navigation under Interest Groups. 

We launched the Community Feedback list - Read the full blog post here‚ÄØ  

  • Available inside the Community Corner‚ÄØgroup, the Feedback list is for the SAP Community team to provide continuous updates on submitted ideas, feedback, and bugs. Although it is not possible for members to publish their direct ideas, all the feedback that has been published in the discussions or sent via inbox will be added by the team. This is a common place to track the progress of enhancements, bugs, and errors. Users can also like and comment on the different items in the list, which helps understand what must be changed/prioritized.  

SAP Glow: New Design- Read the full blog post here  ‚ÄØ  

  • Launch of the new design platform from Project Glow. Elements of the redesign included the introduction of‚ÄØ72 font‚ÄØ(SAP‚Äôs typeface), new iconography (and removal of pictograms), and a lighter aesthetic and softer shape. 

Humanizing moderation- Read the full blog post here  

  • Introduction of a new process for identifying why the moderation alert has been raised. By differentiating non-DSA and DSA reports, we took a step to make moderation friendlier, but we continue ensuring that SAP Community complies with DSA, protecting our site and our members from the illegal activities that the regulations cover. 

August Enhancements- Read the full blog post here   

  • Share buttons (Copy link, Bluesky and LinkedIn) available in blog posts, questions, discussions, events, and knowledge-based documents 
  • Fixed bugs in the notifications page 
  • Sort Options inside the knowledge base, allowing to sort documents by creation date, most recent, most viewed, most commented, and most liked. 

New Q&A badges- Read the full blog post here  ‚ÄØ  

  • Badges for answering questions that were accepted as a solution. Is it possible to earn up to five badges, depending on the number of solutions you provided in Q&A. 

Dark Mode and new Events calendar- Read the full blog post here   

  • Expansion of the Events page with filtering options for countries and a filter for SAP Managed Tags that allows you to get specific when searching for events that match your interests. 
  • Dark-mode options started to be available on the platform, but it is still in a beta phase. 

Badges for kudos received- Read the full blog post here  ‚ÄØ  

  • To improve SAP Community gamification rewards, we launched the progression set of badges for Kudos received, starting from 1 up to 500 Kudos. 

Badges for kudos given - Read the full blog post here ‚ÄØ  

  • Considering the progression set for Kudos received, we also recognized the members given support by launching the badges for Kudos given as well.  

New intelligent search - Read the full blog post here  

  • Beta Search introduced several new filtering options, including the ability to filter by SAP Managed Tag and by question status such as unanswered questions. 

Blog posts published badges - Read the full blog post here   

  • Brand new progression set exclusively for bloggers, rewarding members that have been published from 1 blog post to 30 publications.  

New developer forums - Read the full blog post here   

  • ‚ÄØNew home‚ÄØfor our developers and technical audience in the SAP Community with the following topics:‚ÄØABAP, Artificial Intelligence, SAP CAP, Data and Analytics, Frontend / UI5 / SAP Fiori, Integration and Tooling, including SAP Build. 

September Enhancements- Read the full blog post here  ‚ÄØ  

  • New Standards for Tags and Labels that Enables only 10 SAP Managed Tags, user tags and ten labels per piece of content.‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 
  • <code> tag -‚ÄØAbility to inline <code> HTML element in the body of a post, which will be displayed its contents styled in a colored monospaced font.‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 
  • Table of Contents (TOC) -‚ÄØFunctionality that allows you to add the Table of Contents for blog posts and documents (Knowledge Base articles).‚ÄØ This button will open a ‚ÄúManaged Table of Contents‚Äù to give you a preview and options overview.‚ÄØ 
  • Dismissible Global Banner -‚ÄØThe team heard our members request and now it is possible to find the button ‚ÄúX‚Äù in the banner, which will be removed until a new banner is added.  
  • Glow/Dark were fixed and now the Label widget has been hidden in some boards, the ‚ÄúBoard‚Äù word has also been removed from the top of the feed (allowing the content to be moved up) and ‚Äúspacing‚Äù around headers in post is fixed.‚ÄØ 
  • The Creation Date sorting option has been added to all feeds, making it easier to organize and view posts when they were created. 

Happy Holidays! 

With your support and constant engagement, we can continue spreading high-quality information about various SAP Topics and create a strong community worldwide. It is great to count on your collaboration and feedback to keep our platform moving. We wish you an incredibly happy end of the year and that you have a wonderful time enjoying the holidays! See you next year!

entry.title: SAP Community Hobbies Series: Traveling with My little Puppy and Finding Balance Beyond Tech :)
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

My name is Marla. I work as a Senior Data and AI Developer, and Today, I‚Äôd like to share a bit about my hobby as a part of the  SAP Community Hobbies series. ü§ó Outside of work, one hobby has become very important to me over the last few years: traveling and exploring the world with my little puppy Carlo üòÉ üê∂

It might sound simple, but it requires a lot of planning and creativity. How I organize my trips has also influenced how I think about systems and processes. Carlo is not just my travel companion. He is part of the journey and the reason many of these experiences exist in the first place.

How and when did I start this hobby?

I did not plan for this to become a hobby. It started naturally when I got Carlo five years ago and realized I did not want to stop traveling or leave him alone while I‚Äôm on vacation ü•π. So naturally, instead of adapting my life to travel, I adapted travel to my life.üòâ

Short trips, nature-focused destinations, dog-friendly cities and countries  ( I can totally recommend Croatia and Italy ), and flexible planning became the default. Over time, this turned into a routine and something I actively look forward to. Together, Carlo, my partner Niklas, and I have discovered many new places, from quiet nature spots to vibrant cities, always at a pace that works for all of us.

 

 

Me and Carlo on the way to attend a workshop in Belgrade- Serbia

 

visiting the stunning Externsteine in the Teutoburg Forest - Germany

 Having the best time in The Hague - the Netherlands

 

What do I love most about it?

The biggest value is presence. Traveling with a dog forces you to slow down. You walk more, you observe more, and you plan less around attractions and more around experiences. It clears my head in a way that very few things do, especially after intense project phases or long weeks in front of screens. It is also grounding. No notifications matter when you are on a forest path with a leash in your hand, or when Carlo decides that a certain spot is worth stopping for.

Challenges and how I deal with them

Traveling with a dog is not always easy. Not every hotel is dog-friendly. Public transport rules vary(For example, in Austria, Carlo has to wear a muzzle when using public transportation üòÖ ). Planning takes more effort, especially across countries. I learned to research carefully, build buffers, and always have a backup plan.

A proud moment

My proudest moments are not big milestones. They are small wins. The first long train trip went smoothly. The first international trip without stress. Finding places where Carlo is relaxed, welcome, and curious rather than overwhelmed.

Those moments tell me that good preparation pays off.

Celebrating a friend's birthday in Zaragoza - Spain

 

 

 

Traviling to Berlin for TechEd 2025

 

 

flying to Mallorca -Spain

 

enjoying a ride in Texel- the Netherlands

Tools and resources for beginners

For anyone starting out, these are essential:

Dog-friendly accommodation platforms and search filters
Basic travel gear such as a good leash, a portable water bowl, and a transport-safe harness
Patience and realistic expectations. You do not need expensive equipment. You need planning and awareness.

 

Chilling at the Hotel in k√ºlingsborn-Germany

 

 

Flying to Spain again üòÑ

 

 

 

Road trips with the car

 

Tips for getting started

Start small.üòâ Begin with day trips, then weekends, then longer journeys. Observe how your dog reacts and adjust. Do not aim for perfection. Aim for learning. The same applies to learning new SAP technologies. Iteration beats overplanning.

How I keep improving

I learn by doing. Each trip teaches me something new. Traveling with Carlo constantly challenges me to be more flexible and attentive. I also exchange tips with other dog owners and travelers. Reflection after each journey helps me improve the next one. Continuous improvement does not need formal training. It needs attention.

Common misconceptions

A common myth is that traveling with a dog is restrictive.In reality, it changes priorities, but it also opens new perspectives. You discover quieter places, nature-focused destinations, and a slower pace that many people are actually looking for.

Visiting Heidelberg

 

 

Carlo in Berlin üòÑ

 

 

Chilling in Mallorca

Where to learn more

There are many blogs and communities focused on dog-friendly travel, especially in Europe and North America. Local communities are often more helpful than large platforms.

The connection to the SAP world

The connection is stronger than it seems.

Traveling with a dog is about systems thinking. You balance constraints, dependencies, timing, and user experience, where the user just happens to have four legs.

In SAP projects, especially in data and AI, we design architectures that must be robust, flexible, and humane. This hobby constantly reminds me that good systems serve real needs, not just technical elegance.It also helps me show up better at work. More focused, more patient, and more grounded.

What is next?

After discovering so many places together, our next big plan is to cross the Atlantic. Carlo and I are preparing for a longer journey, with New York and Toronto at the top of the list. It will be a new level of planning, learning, and adapting, and I am already looking forward to what we will discover next.

Thanks for reading. If you travel with your dog, or if you have found a hobby that helps you disconnect and think better, I would love to hear about it.

 

Hello from Karlsruhe

Coming up  next ü•Å

I am happy to pass the baton to  @HakanHasalman, who will introduce his writing hobby. ü§ó

 

With Love,
Marla & Carlo

entry.title: Extending an SAP Sample Sankey Custom Widget in SAP Analytics Cloud to Deliver Top-N Hierarchical In
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) does not provide a native, built-in Sankey chart as part of its standard visualization catalog. As a result, Sankey-style visualizations in SAC are typically implemented using custom widgets.

In mid-2024, while working on an enterprise analytics engagement, I encountered a requirement to visualize:

  • Top N parent entities (for example, service providers)
  • And, for each parent, the Top M child entities independently ranked per parent (for example, services offered)

All of this needed to be displayed within a single Sankey visualization, enabling users to immediately understand concentration and distribution patterns without navigating multiple charts.

To address this requirement, I explored SAC‚Äôs Custom Widget framework and extended an existing SAP-provided sample Sankey custom widget into a production-ready solution.

I have intentionally included the development and deployment steps in detail so that consultants or developers who are completely new to Sankey custom widgets in SAP Analytics Cloud can deploy and validate the solution end-to-end by following this blog.

SAP Sample Sankey Custom Widget as the Starting Point

Since SAP Analytics Cloud does not include a native Sankey chart, I referred to a sample Sankey custom widget implementation shared by SAP through the SAP Community. This SAP-provided sample demonstrates how a Sankey diagram can be rendered using the SAC Custom Widget framework and served as a technical starting point for my work.

The SAP sample was very helpful as a technical reference, as it illustrated:

  • Custom widget structure and lifecycle
  • Binding SAC model data to a widget
  • Rendering a Sankey diagram using JavaScript

During mid-2024, while actively working on this requirement, I engaged in the comments section of that SAP Community blog (SAP Analytics Cloud: Custom Widget & Widget Add-Ons Samples Preview) under my SAP Community user@GovindaRaoBanothu45 , discussing feasibility and implementation boundaries.

While the sample clarified the basic rendering approach, it also highlighted functional gaps when applied to enterprise-scale analytical requirements.

Why the SAP Sample Sankey Widget Was Not Sufficient

The SAP-provided Sankey custom widget was intentionally designed as a generic sample. Its behavior was to render all nodes and all links returned by the bound dataset.

However, the sample widget did not support the enterprise analytical requirement I was addressing, specifically:

  • No Top-N filtering at the parent level
  • No independent ranking of child nodes per parent
  • No data trimming prior to Sankey rendering
  • Limited usability for large, real-world datasets

As a result, while the SAP sample demonstrated how to render a Sankey chart, it did not meet the analytical or usability needs of an enterprise dashboard.

This gap required extending and enhancing the SAP sample Sankey custom widget with additional, original logic to reshape the dataset before rendering.

High-Level Architecture of the Extended Sankey Widget

The Sankey rendering mechanism remains aligned with the SAP sample, while the data-transformation layer represents the core extension.

Development Environment and Prerequisites

Prerequisites

To get started, ensure that you have:

  • Access to SAP Analytics Cloud with Optimized Design Experience enabled
  • Node.js installed on your local machine
  • Visual Studio Code (VS Code) installed
  • Basic understanding of JavaScript and JSON

Development Environment Setup

Install Node.js

  1. Download Node.js from: https://nodejs.org
  2. Verify installation:
node -v
npm -v

Install Visual Studio Code

  1. Download VS Code from: https://code.visualstudio.com
  2. Use VS Code as the primary editor for developing and maintaining the custom widget files.

Set Up the Project Folder

  1. Create a project folder (for example, SankeySAPcode).
  2. Open the folder in Visual Studio Code.
  3. Create the following files:
  • main.js ‚Äì core widget logic and Sankey rendering
  • index.json ‚Äì metadata and resource configuration
  • hash256.js ‚Äì Node.js script for integrity key generation

Sankey Custom Widget ‚Äì Standard Project Structure

For the standard Sankey implementation, I created a dedicated project folder (for example, SankeySAPcode or any relevant project name). This folder contains all the supporting and required files needed to build and deploy the Sankey custom widget in SAP Analytics Cloud.

The project folder includes:

  • main.js
    The web component JavaScript file that contains the core widget logic and Sankey rendering code (mandatory).
  • index.json
    The metadata file that defines the custom widget, its properties, and resource references (mandatory).
  • sankeyChartStyling.js
    An optional styling component used to expose styling options in the widget‚Äôs styling panel (optional).
  • build/ folder
    Contains the helper script hash256.js, which is used to generate SHA-256 integrity keys for the JavaScript files.

Note: Styling files (Styling.js, sankeyChartStyling.js, or xxxxStyling.js) are optional and may not be required for all custom widgets.
However, the web component JavaScript file (main.js or equivalent) and the metadata file (index.json) are mandatory for every SAP Analytics Cloud custom widget. The build folder is included purely for maintainability and ease of understanding.
Technically, the hash256.js file can also be placed directly in the main project folder. Including it in a separate subfolder is optional and does not impact deployment, as long as the final ZIP file complies with SAP Analytics Cloud‚Äôs upload requirements.

Creating Integrity Keys and Deploying the Code

SAP Analytics Cloud supports SHA-256 integrity validation to ensure uploaded JavaScript resources are not modified.

Generating Integrity Keys

  1. Open a Node.js command prompt
  2. Navigate to the folder containing hash256.js
  3. Execute the script

Example output:

  • main.js: sha256-6134FFLCQYpH7x8gx29H1xJyRbitpf/guj5UGKhJ25Q=
  • sankeyChartStyling.js:  sha256-AR0uDO+9h8nu9EyJotSinZ2APDWD5Ja2JmdFcZCH1Xo=

Note: If additional JavaScript resource files are included, their corresponding sha256- integrity keys must also be added to the index.json file under the resources section.

Similarly, the file names must be updated in hash256.js before generating integrity keys for those files.

Core Enhancement: Top-N Parent and Top-M Child Logic

The following snippets are representative excerpts from the working implementation.
Full scripts are intentionally not published, as this widget was delivered as part of an enterprise engagement.

In the widget, the SAC data binding is first normalized into an array (data) containing parent node, child node, and measure value fields.

Step 1: Aggregate Measure by Parent

const parentTotals = {};
data.forEach(row => {
  parentTotals[row.parentNode] =
    (parentTotals[row.parentNode] || 0) + Number(row.measureValue);
});

Step 2: Rank and Retain Top-N Parents

const topParents = Object.entries(parentTotals)
  .sort((a, b) => b[1] - a[1])
  .slice(0, TOP_N_PARENT_NODES)
  .map(entry => entry[0]);

Step 3: Rank and Retain Top-M Children per Parent

const filteredLinks = [];
topParents.forEach(parent => {
  const children = data
    .filter(row => row.parentNode === parent)
    .sort((a, b) => b.measureValue - a.measureValue)
    .slice(0, TOP_N_CHILD_NODES);

  children.forEach(child => {
    filteredLinks.push({
      source: parent,
      target: child.childNode,
      value:  child.measureValue
    });
  });
});

Step 4: Rebuild Nodes

const nodes = [...new Set(
  filteredLinks.flatMap(l => [l.source, l.target])
)].map(name => ({ name }));

Step 5: Render Sankey

sankey.nodes(nodes).links(filteredLinks).layout(32);

The rendering follows the SAP sample approach; the innovation lies in the data-transformation logic.

Once all required files and script updates are ready, let‚Äôs deploy the custom widget into SAP Analytics Cloud.

Deploy the Custom Widget

  1. Create a ZIP File:
    • Include main.js, index.json, and optional styling files in a .zip file.
  2. Upload to SAP Analytics Cloud:
    • Navigate to the Custom Widgets section in SAC.
    • Upload the .json and .zip files.
  3. Test the Widget:
    • Add the custom widget to a story and configure data sources.

Select the JSON metadata file from your local system.

Next, select the resource file that is .zip file of main.js, index.json and styling.js or any other file related to this chart.

Now you can the widget in "Custom Widgets" section.

Observe the warning messages below with and/without integrity checks in the list of custom widgets

We have done custom widget deployment and will use the same in stories. Let's see how to access this in story 2.0.

 

From the builder panel, select your data model, set measure, set a hierarchical dimension and edit the default colors of the different depths from the Styling panel.

Below screenshot show the usage of the Styling.JS file.

In case the java script files get modified / tampered you get the below error while creating chart using custom widget in SAC story.

Validated Sankey Variants  - Let's validate 3 different scenarios

  • SAP sample Sankey (baseline):

                          

  • Top 1 parent + Top 5 child nodes:
    • This is the custom code and the main.js file is completely different than standard code with the key components are the below conditions below.

                        

                       Result of the above changes,

                    

  • Top 3 parents + Top 5 children:

                          

                        Result of the above changes,

                       

This incremental approach helped validate correctness before applying the logic to larger Top-N configurations.

Acknowledgment

I would like to thank @marouferchichi for actively engaging in the SAP Community blog comments and helping clarify the capabilities and boundaries of the sample Sankey custom widget.

The final implementation described here represents my independent extension and delivery of that sample to meet enterprise-level analytical requirements.

Conclusion

This blog demonstrates how a SAP sample Sankey custom widget can be extended into a production-grade Top-N hierarchical Sankey visualization using SAP Analytics Cloud‚Äôs Custom Widget framework.

For similar enterprise scenarios, this approach provides a reusable and scalable pattern.

entry.title: My Journey into the SAP World: From Campus to BASIS Administrator
entry.content:
The Beginning

I graduated in 2025 and, through campus placements, landed an opportunity with a company called Mindsprint. At first, I was a little concerned about the role, but I decided to take the offer and explore SAP. I kept thinking, ‚ÄúMaybe God has a better plan for me.‚Äù

I started as an intern for about six months. To be honest, during the internship, there weren‚Äôt many tasks. Most of my time went into researching SAP BASIS concepts, but without access to a production system, learning was slow. Thankfully, with my team‚Äôs support, I converted to a full-time role‚Äîand that‚Äôs when the real journey began.

Where I Am Today

It‚Äôs been about four months since I officially entered the SAP field, and my role is BASIS Administrator. So far, I‚Äôve worked on:

  • Transport Requests (TR) Movements
  • Kernel Upgrades
  • HDB Client Upgrade
  • Exposure to ChaRM, CALM, and BTP Administration

I‚Äôve been lucky to have a great team and plenty of opportunities to learn. But recently, I‚Äôve started noticing repetitive tasks, and that got me thinking: What‚Äôs next?

SAP: An Ocean of Opportunities

SAP feels like an ocean‚Äîso many things to explore! I want to grow in this field, learn what‚Äôs trending, and stay ahead. My seniors say I‚Äôve had good exposure already, but I‚Äôm hungry for more.

For context, I have a B.Tech in CSE, so coding isn‚Äôt new to me. Recently, I explored SAP BTP with Terraform, which was exciting. But now, I‚Äôm wondering:
‚úÖ What should I learn next?
‚úÖ What‚Äôs the future of SAP?
‚úÖ Which skills will help me stand out in the market?

Your Guidance Matters

If you‚Äôre experienced in SAP or have insights into the latest trends, I‚Äôd love your suggestions. Should I dive deeper into BTP, Cloud, Automation, or something else?

SAP is vast, and I want to make sure I‚Äôm swimming in the right direction. Your advice could help shape my next steps!

 

Thanks for reading my story! If you‚Äôve been on a similar journey or have tips for someone starting out, please share. Let‚Äôs learn and grow together!

entry.title: Introduction
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community!

I am excited to start my journey in the SAP Community. My goal is to learn how to get started, explore tips for meaningful participation, and connect with experts and fellow learners. The SAP Community Welcome Corner has been a great guide, helping me make the most of this collaborative space. Through this blog, I will share my experiences, insights, and discoveries as I navigate the community and grow my SAP skills.

I look forward to learning, sharing, growing, and actively participating in the SAP Community.

Best Regards,

Yugandhar

entry.title: Accessing SAP BTP Core Services APIs Using SAP Cloud Management Service (CIS)
entry.content:
Accessing SAP Cloud Integration (SAP CI) information programmatically has become quite common today.
Whether it‚Äôs iFlows, message processing logs, or deployed artifacts, SAP CI OData APIs make this information easily available, all we need is SAP CI technical user with the right roles.

This convenience often raises a natural question:

Can we do the same for SAP BTP as well?

Can we programmatically access:

  • SAP BTP account details ?
  • Subaccounts and entitlements ?
  • Services and runtime information ?

The answer is Yes, but unlike SAP CI, the authentication and access model for SAP BTP Core Services is fundamentally different.

 

Why SAP BTP Is Different from SAP CI?

When accessing SAP CI OData APIs, authentication is straightforward:

  • Use an SAP CI technical user
  • Assign the required roles
  • Call the OData endpoint

However, SAP BTP Core Services APIs (Accounts, Entitlements, Directories, etc.) do not work this way.

One cannot:

  • Use SAP CI technical users
  • Use basic authentication
  • Directly call these APIs without a management service
SAP BTP protects these APIs using OAuth 2.0 and requires a dedicated management service to act as a trusted client.
And this is exactly where the SAP Cloud Management Service (CIS) comes into play.
 

Introducing SAP Cloud Management Service (CIS)

To access SAP BTP Core Services APIs, SAP mandates the use of: SAP Cloud Management Service ‚Äì CIS plan

CIS acts as:

  • An authorized OAuth client
  • A secure gateway to SAP BTP management APIs
  • The mechanism through which access tokens are issued for Core Services

Once CIS is configured, SAP Cloud Integration can securely access SAP BTP Core Services APIs.

 

Create SAP Cloud Management Service Instance

Step 1: BTP Cockpit --> Subaccount --> Service Marketplace --> Search ‚ÄúCIS‚Äù

Step 2: Create an instance of CIS using the three dots present on the top right of the tile.

Pick ‚Äúcentral-viewer‚Äù as the plan and click on create

You can check the scope of each plan here : SAP Cloud Management Service - Service Plans | SAP Help Portal
Once this step is done, CIS will be available in the Instances column of the subaccount.

Step 3: Now create a Service key for this instance.

As soon as service key is created ServiceKey cis.json file is ready for the download.

The JSON looks like this :

Among the endpoints in the above picture, our focus is on the endpoint, which will give us the details related to SAP BTP Account.

"accounts_service_url": "https://accounts-service.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com"

Now to access this URL, we need to setup OAuth 2.0 Credentials on SAP CI using the details provided in this JSON file.

 

Setting up OAuth 2.0 Credentials on SAP CI

Refer the JSON file and configure the security artifact as shown below.

Token Service URL : <<uaa_url>>/oauth/token
Client ID : << clientid >>
Client Secret : << clientsecret >>
Custom Parameters : grantType : clientCredentials
 

SAP CI Iflow:

We have all the configuration in place, now the most interesting part, lets deploy and test the flow.

HTTP Adapter Configurations:

Base URL: https://accounts-service.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com (can be found in the JSON file)
Resource to fetch information of Global Account: /accounts/v1/globalAccount 

Address: https://accounts-service.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/accounts/v1/globalAccount

Other resources of this API can be found here https://api.sap.com/package/SAPCloudPlatformCoreServices/rest

Credentails Name: As created above

 

Demo:

Lets deploy and execute the flow now:

 

 

Response: The information of the SAP BTP Global Account is seen in the response.

 

Conclusion:

SAP BTP Core Services APIs follow a different and more secure access model. These APIs are protected using OAuth 2.0 and require the SAP Cloud Management Service (CIS) as the authorized gateway.

Once CIS is configured, consuming SAP BTP Core Services APIs from SAP Cloud Integration becomes seamless, enabling automation, governance, and platform-level insights. Understanding this distinction is essential for designing robust and future-ready integration scenarios on SAP BTP.

Hope this helps!

Cheers,

Punith

entry.content:
‚ÄÉ

Hello dear SAP Community! 

We hope this message finds you well and that you're starting the new year with excitement and positivity! As we kick off this fresh chapter, we‚Äôre reaching out to invite you to play a crucial role in shaping the future of our community.

Why Participate?

  1. Shape the Future: Your input will help us understand your needs and preferences, allowing us to tailor our future community initiatives accordingly.
  2. Quick and Easy: The survey takes just a few minutes of your time and can be completed from your smartphone or computer.

How to Join:

Simply click on this survey link and share your thoughts with us! Alternatively, you can also access the survey by scanning this QR-Code:

Rest assured, all responses are anonymous. 

What Happens to Your Responses?

Once the survey concludes, we will carefully analyze the results and share a report summary with you. This will give you insights into how your opinions compare with others and what steps we plan to take next.

Your Voice is Important!

Whether you‚Äôre a frequent community member or this is your first time, your input makes a difference. We‚Äôre excited to hear from you and work together to strengthen our community.

Please help us spread the word and win a meet and greet with Josh Bentley, Head of SAP Community! 

The more voices we hear, the better we can address our community‚Äôs needs. üòäSo please help us and share the survey link with friends and peers! And as a token of our appreciation, helping us spread the word enters you into a draw to win a personal meet & greet with Josh Bentley, head of SAP Community! Thank you in advance for your participation and support!

Warm regards and HAPPY NEW YEAR 2026!
Mynyna

entry.title: Cloud Integration - Synchronizing BTP Accounts into SAP LeanIX using the SAP LeanIX Adapter
entry.content:
Introduction

As IT landscapes expand across cloud platforms, regions, and teams, transparency and governance become just as important as connectivity. Knowing that systems are connected is not enough, you also need to understand what exists, why it exists, who owns it, and how it fits into the overall enterprise architecture.

A very common example of this challenge can be seen with SAP BTP. Organizations start with a few Global and Subaccounts for specific projects, but over time the landscape grows. New subaccounts are created for pilots, innovations, regional teams, and temporary initiatives. Months later, questions start surfacing:

  • How many SAP BTP accounts do we actually have?
  • Which ones are actively used versus idle?
  • Who is responsible for each account?
  • How do these technical setups align with business capabilities and strategy?

Without a structured approach to documentation and governance, SAP BTP landscapes can quickly lose clarity which makes audits, cost optimization, and strategic decisions difficult.

This is where Enterprise Architecture Management and tools like LeanIX play a crucial role.

What is SAP LeanIX?

SAP LeanIX is a Enterprise Architecture (EA) and IT Portfolio Management solution that helps companies visualize, analyze, and modernize their IT landscapes.

Key Functions & Benefits:

  • Application Portfolio Management (APM): Creates clear, up-to-date application inventories to identify redundancies and reduce tech debt.
  • Roadmap & Architecture Planning: Aligns IT strategy with business goals, planning future landscapes for changes like cloud migrations or AI.
  • Transformation Guidance: Helps navigate complex projects, such as ERP (SAP S/4HANA), mergers, and SaaS adoption.
  • IT Risk Management: Manages technology obsolescence and compliance risks, notes the SAP Help Portal.
  • Business Capability Mapping: Connects business processes to underlying applications and technology. 

LeanIX focuses heavily on data-driven architecture decisions, ensuring that architecture is not just diagrams, but living documentation.

Understanding Fact Sheets in LeanIX

Fact Sheets are the core building blocks of LeanIX. They are structured data objects used to represent key elements of your enterprise architecture, such as applications, IT components, interfaces, business capabilities, organizations, and technical platforms.

Each Fact Sheet captures:

  • Essential metadata (name, lifecycle, status)
  • Relationships between architecture elements
  • Ownership and responsibility information

Fact Sheets act as a single source of truth for your architecture landscape.

Why Fact Sheets Matter

Fact Sheets help you:

  • Move away from Excel-based documentation
  • Keep architecture data consistent and up to date
  • Visualize dependencies and impact
  • Support audits, compliance, and informed decision-making

In this blog, we will use Fact Sheets to represent SAP BTP accounts in LeanIX.

Integration Scenario Overview

In this scenario, we build an integration that provides end-to-end visibility of SAP BTP accounts in LeanIX.

The integration flow performs the following steps:

  • SAP Cloud Integration (CI) retrieves details of:
    • SAP BTP Global Accounts
    • SAP BTP Subaccounts
  • The retrieved data is transformed into a LeanIX-compatible structure
  • LeanIX Fact Sheets are then created or updated using the LeanIX Adapter, ensuring the information in LeanIX remains consistent and up to date

This integration is based on SAP Standard Integration Content available in the Discover tab of SAP Cloud Integration/SAP Business Accelerator hub https://api.sap.com/integrationflow/Fullsync_SAP_BTP_Account_Structure . Since the core flow is already provided by SAP, this blog does not cover every palette or step in detail.

The focus is on a key enhancement:
the standard content uses an HTTP adapter to communicate with LeanIX, which has been updated to use the native LeanIX Adapter to meet the use case.

Why Integrate SAP BTP with LeanIX?

As SAP BTP landscapes grow across regions, teams, and projects, maintaining governance becomes challenging. Without visibility, organizations risk unused subaccounts, unclear ownership, and compliance issues. Integrating SAP BTP with LeanIX ensures architecture data stays up to date, provides real-time visibility, and enables informed, data-driven decisions.

LeanIX Adapter in SAP Cloud Integration

SAP Cloud Integration provides a native LeanIX Adapter, making it easier to interact with LeanIX APIs without building everything from scratch.

  • Supports GraphQL variant that allows you to manage FactSheets using standard operations like Create, Get, Update etc.
  • GraphQL variant allows you to specify requirements using Advanced Query feature.
  • Supports REST variant to manage entities like Bookmarks and Settings using CRUD operations.
  • Offers secure authentication via LeanIX OAuth option which employs OAuth authentication.

SAP LeanIX Setup:

Lets start with creating a technical User on LeanIX , because we need the API token to interact with the application

Step 1: In the user profile menu, select Administration, and then go to Technical Users.

Step 2: Create a new Technical User.

Step 3: As soon as you create a technical user, an API Token is generated. Make sure the token is saved as it displays only once

Now, we are all good on Lean IX end.

Deploy this token as a Secure Parameter under Security Artifact in SAP CI

Configurations on SAP BTP.

We make use of SAP BTP Core Services APIs to fetch details of SAP BTP accounts. To enable this, a SAP Cloud Management Service (CIS) instance must be created in the SAP BTP subaccount.

For a detailed, step-by-step guide on:

  • Creating a service instance and service key for CIS
  • Configuring OAuth credentials in SAP Cloud Integration
  • Configuring HTTP Adapter to fetch the information of the SAP BTP Accounts

Please refer to the following blog: Accessing SAP BTP Core Services APIs Using SAP Cloud Management Service (CIS)

SAP CI IFlow:

As mentioned above, the iflow design is referenced from an existing iflow present on Discover tab, you can also locate this on SAP Business Accelerator Hub : https://api.sap.com/integrationflow/Fullsync_SAP_BTP_Account_Structure 

Request Body to create Level 1 Factsheet:

{
  "query": "mutation ($input: BaseFactSheetInput!, $patches: [Patch]!) { createFactSheet(input: $input, patches: $patches) { factSheet { id name type ... on Platform { description name } } } }",
  "variables": {
    "input": {
      "name": "Trail SAP BTP Account",
      "type": "Platform"
    },
    "patches": [
      {
        "op": "add",
        "path": "/description",
        "value": "Global Account FactSheet created automatically by SAP Integration Suite."
      }
    ]
  }
}

In this updated version, I have used LeanIX adapter to connect to LeanIX system, the configuration of LeanIX Adapter is shown below.

LeanIX Adapter in SAP CI has two variants, In this design GraphQL Variant is used

Configuration of LeanIX Adapter

Connection Tab:

 
Parameter
Value
Comments
Address
https://<<domain>>.leanix.net
SAP LeanIX endpoint
Authentication
LeanIX OAuth
To use LeanIX API Token for authentication
API Token Alias
LeanIX
Secure Parameter which was created in the steps above
Reuse Connection
Yes/No
Enable if the connection needs to be reused
Connection Timeout
60000
Specify the maximum waiting time (in milliseconds) while establishing a connection with LeanIX
Respone Timeout
60000
Specify the maximum waiting time (in milliseconds) ) for a response to be received from LeanIX.
 

Processing Tab:

The Objective is create Factsheet on LeanIX, Configure the operation and entity as shown below

All set! lets go for the demo now.

Demo:

We are all set on SAP BTP, SAP CI and LeanIX end. Lets deploy the iflow and check the results.

SAP BTP Account:

This is how the SAP BTP account is structured. Now lets check how the Fact Sheets  are created on the LeanIX side.

SAP LeanIX:

The data is successfully integrated in LeanIX and Factsheets are created.

SAP BTP Account was one global Account and 3 Subaccounts,

Factsheet 1: This sheet shows that the BTP Account has 1 Global Account

Factsheet 2: This sheet shows that the BTP Account has 1 Global Account and there are 3 Subaccounts linked to it (shown as 3 children), You can also see all the relevant tags like ‚ÄúTRAIL‚Äù, ‚ÄúSubscription‚Äù

 

Factsheet 3: This sheet talks about the subaccount ‚ÄúDevelopment‚Äù, it is linked to the Parent Factsheet which is related to the Global Account

Similarly there are two more factsheets for Quality and Production Subaccounts, In total creating 5 Factsheets on SAP LeanIX

With this integration in place, SAP BTP account data is no longer just operational information, it becomes architectural knowledge. By synchronizing SAP BTP Global and Subaccount details into LeanIX Fact Sheets using SAP Cloud Integration and the LeanIX Adapter, we establish a single, governed view of the cloud landscape.

What was previously scattered across platforms is now visible, structured, and actionable. Architects and stakeholders can clearly understand ownership, lifecycle, and usage of SAP BTP accounts without manual documentation or spreadsheets.

But this is only the beginning.

What More Can Be Done?

This opens up several powerful possibilities beyond basic Fact Sheet creation:

  • Maintain relationships between Fact Sheets
    (e.g., linking BTP accounts to applications, integrations, or business capabilities)
  • Enrich Fact Sheets with custom attributes such as cost center, environment, or compliance tags
  • Synchronize lifecycle states automatically based on real usage
  • Detect and manage redundancies across accounts and platforms
  • Enable impact analysis by visualizing dependencies across your architecture

By combining runtime integration data with enterprise architecture governance, LeanIX transforms Fact Sheets from static records into living architecture assets.

 

Hope this helps!

Cheers,

Punith

entry.title: The Curious Case of SAP Community Moderation: A Study in Arbitrary Excellence
entry.content:
The Curious Case of SAP Community Moderation: A Study in Arbitrary Excellence

There's something almost admirable about a system so perfectly calibrated to frustrate its most dedicated contributors. SAP Community's moderation team has achieved what few organisations dare to attempt: the complete democratisation of confusion.

The Algorithm Knows Best

Picture this: you've spent hours crafting a technical blog post. You hit publish. Within moments, the machine learning system ‚Äî trained, presumably, by a committee of caffeinated squirrels ‚Äî determines your carefully researched content is indistinguishable from Nigerian prince correspondence. Welcome to spam jail.

But fear not! The moderators check the filter "regularly." Your content will resurface within 24 business hours. Or minutes. Or perhaps never. The timeline, much like the moderation logic itself, remains charmingly mysterious.

A Tale of Two Blogs

Here's where it gets genuinely fascinating.

A blog post about shell command execution in SAP CPI  ‚Äî

https://community.sap.com/t5/integration-blog-posts/getting-unconventional-with-groovy-part-1-executing-shell-commands-reading/ba-p/14294407#M2049

 

one that, by the author's own assessment, "doesn't reveal 10% of what already existing articles reveal" ‚Äî gets nuked from orbit.

Meanwhile, this gem about terminal access to CPI runtime 

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/terminal-access-to-cpi-runtime-execution-of-shell-commands-on-cpi-runtime/ba-p/13460198

has been sunbathing peacefully on the platform for five years. Five. Years.

And what about this post detailing PGP secret keyring handling 

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/pgp-secret-keyring-in-cpi-the-lost-passphrase-recovery/ba-p/13491284

? If we're genuinely concerned about security implications, one might think exposing cryptographic key management deserves more scrutiny than reading a file via shell script. But no. That one's fine. Perfectly fine.

The logic? There isn't any. Or if there is, it's locked in a vault somewhere, guarded by the same people who decided "Moderator 972001" was an appropriately human identifier.

The Silence Says Everything

When these inconsistencies are raised ‚Äî politely at first, then with understandable frustration ‚Äî the response is instructive in its absence.

No explanation. No acknowledgment. No "we'll look into it."

Just the digital equivalent of being shown the door while someone pretends to be very busy with paperwork.

As one contributor put it: "Is there no accountability left?"

The answer, delivered through elegant silence, appears to be: correct.

Transparency? Never Heard of Her

The moderation team operates with the transparency of a brick wall painted black and placed in a basement with no stairs. Decisions materialise from the void. Appeals dissolve into it.

"Moderator 972001" ‚Äî a designation that radiates all the warmth and humanity of a tax audit ‚Äî can apparently remove two blogs in three days from the same contributor without so much as a form letter explaining why.

One might ask: is this moderator a real person? A bot? A random number generator with delete privileges?

The community may never know. And that, apparently, is by design.

The God Complex, Quantified

There's a specific institutional pathology at play here. It's the quiet arrogance of systems that punish engagement, reward silence, and treat questions about their own behaviour as an inconvenience.

When contributors ask "Are the moderators operating in good faith?" ‚Äî a reasonable question given the evidence ‚Äî the absence of any response tells you everything.

In Conclusion

The SAP Community moderation team has built something remarkable: a platform where the most knowledgeable contributors are rewarded with suspicion, inconsistency, and bureaucratic indifference.

One needn't resort to profanity to describe them. Their work speaks eloquently enough.
